reviewText: The Shortest Way Home about C.S. Lewis was very concise and informative.

As a C. S. Lewis fanatic, I was excited to pick up this DVD and watch it. "The Shortest Way Home: C. S. Lewis & Mere Christianity" was true to the thoughts of Lewis, but it wasn't anything overly new.  For someone familiar with Lewis and his book "Mere Chistianity," there probably is not anything here that will add much to what they already know.

The film follows the outline of Lewis' book rather closely. It serves, in a way, as a summary of and minor commentary on Lewis' thoughts in "Mere Christianity."

Interspersed throughout are small "discussions" between someone who is a Christian and someone who is seeking answers while reading the book as a class assignment.  The acting here is not the best, in my opinion, but some of the questions and responses are worth considering.

If you are just getting into Lewis' book yourself, or if you know someone who is, this would make a great companion DVD. Otherwise, there may be other videos that give more insight into Lewis.

As a Lutheran student since Kindergarten through college, the apologetics aspect of finally finding out why we believe what we believe has always been fascinating. When debating the "doorknockers" like JW's and LDS bikers, I embarked on the apologetics line of thinking so finding out what turned an atheist into a believer was likewise interesting. I appreciated Lewis' melding of the philosophical & spiritual reasoning which lead him to his conclusions. I would recommend this film as an introduction to his theological works. But reading his books--as I remember--offered a much better read then reflect pace. The Screwtape Letters was a more entertaining (but substantive) while Mere Christianity is a scholarly search and discover reasoning exercise in why the Christian faith makes sense ultimately.

In advance of starting a "Mere Christianity" book club, I purchased the DVD of "The Shortest Way Home: C.S. Lewis & Mere Christianity," in hopes that it would be a nice informational starting point that we could watch together before jumping into the book, knowing that a bunch of people in our group have not only never read the book but know very little about Lewis.  And I was so disappointed that I decided not to show it at all.

My primary critique is just the cheesiness of the entire production.  The "dialogue" between two college students was downright painful to watch.  The acting was weak, but no one could have saved that script.  There was a totally random and unnecessary scene with the narrator ordering a coffee in the same coffee shop were these gals were chatting.  As I was watching, I was chuckling to myself, thinking, "What in the world is this nonsense?"  And the cheese factor extended to the background scenes which provided a backdrop to the narration, which was a series of weird vignettes from church services or a family eating breakfast together, which had absolutely nothing to do with the material that was being discussed.  It was just painful.

And, frankly, I was unimpressed with the team of interviewed experts, who ranged from boring to rambling.  With all of the genuine Lewis scholars out there, I was baffled that one of the three selected interviewees was the leader of an obscure campus ministry, with no mentioned academic credentials or noteworthy Lewis expertise.  Though there were a few snippets that were valuable and/or interesting, I thought this portion of the production, which could have been the most substantive and insightful, was stale and uninspired.

Ultimately, I just thought this DVD was a mess.  Obviously, others have found it to be helpful, but again, I was so impressed by its amateurish content and style that I didn't even show it to my group.  For a book as substantial and timeless as "Mere Christianity," this hour-long documentary doesn't even remotely do it justice.  If you're looking for some context about "Mere Christianity," I'd recommend Eric Metaxas' "Discussing 'Mere Christianity'" small group DVD curriculum instead (the study guide for which was written by one of this DVD's experts).  Even better, just read Lewis, one of the finest Christian minds and writers in all of history.
